page.title: 02GENERAL VIEW OF ATWORTH
page.content: BUILDINGS_LANDSCAPE_QUARRYING. The community,village,farms and field walls are constructed with local stone and give the area a pleasing aspect.The stone used comes from the Bath stone quarries and the layer of surface Cornbrash.Indeed stone is so plentiful there is only one red brick house in the area,all others being stone or stone faced. The land is undulating & fertile,the underlying clay layer means that wells abound.Consequently building took place over a wide area,a long narrow village developed on both sides of the Bath road. Extensive quarrying,since Roman times,has resulted in the northern part of the block being honeycombed by passages,many of which are now utilised by the military for storage.
